title: How to Make a Simple Chocolate Cake

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and grease 2 9 in (23 cm) pans.
steps.description: Spray the bottom and sides of 2 round cake pans with nonstick baking spray and set them aside. If you don't have spray, butter the pans and sprinkle flour in them. Tap the pans so the flour coats them and then dump out the excess flour. If you're concerned that your cakes will stick, cut parchment paper into circles that fit the bottom of your pans. Press a parchment circle onto the bottom of each pan after you've sprayed or greased them.

steps.headline: Whisk the sugar, flour, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda, and salt in a bowl.
steps.description: Put 2 cups (400 g) of granulated white sugar into a large mixing bowl and add 1 3/4 cups (245 g) of all-purpose flour. Add 3/4 cup (88 g) of unsweetened cocoa powder, 1 1/2 teaspoons (7 g) of baking powder, 1 1/2 teaspoons (6 g) of baking soda, and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 g) of salt. Then, whisk for about 30 seconds to combine the ingredients. Use Dutch-processed or natural unsweetened cocoa. Avoid using a sweetened cocoa mix or your cake won't have a rich chocolate flavor.

steps.headline: Mix 2 eggs with water, milk, oil, and vanilla in a separate bowl.
steps.description: Get out another mixing bowl and crack 2 large eggs into it. Whisk the eggs and add 1 cup (240 ml) of warm water or coffee, 1 cup (240 ml) of milk, ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of oil, and 1 ⁄2 teaspoons (7.4 ml) of vanilla extract. Whisk the mixture for about 20 seconds so the eggs combine with the rest of the wet ingredients.Tip: The coffee won't add a distinct coffee flavor. Instead, it will bring out the chocolate's depth of flavor. Use any flavorless oil, such as corn oil, vegetable oil, safflower oil, or canola oil.

steps.headline: Stir the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients to make a smooth batter.
steps.description: Pour the wet mixture into the bowl with the dry mixture and use a whisk or spoon to mix them. Keep stirring until you don't see any pockets of dry ingredients. Don't worry if the batter looks thin. The moisture in the batter creates a light, moist cake.

steps.headline: Divide the batter between the 2 greased pans.
steps.description: Slowly pour the batter into both of the prepared pans so there's the same amount of batter in each. You can do this by sight or weigh the pans on a scale and adjust the batter as needed. To use a scale, set each filled cake pan on a kitchen scale and see if they weigh about the same. If one is heavier than the other, spoon some of the batter into the other pan.

steps.headline: Bake the chocolate cakes for 27 to 32 minutes.
steps.description: Put both of the filled pans into the preheated oven and bake them until they're dry in the center. To test if they're done, wear oven mitts and carefully stick a skewer or cake tester into the center of a cake. It should come out clean once the cake is done. If the skewer or tester has batter on it, bake the cake for a few minutes and check it again.

steps.headline: Remove the pans from the oven and cool the cakes.
steps.description: Turn off the oven and wear oven mitts to take the pans out. Set them on a wire rack to cool for 10 minutes before you flip them out of the pans onto the wire rack. Let them cool completely. You can decorate the cakes using toppings after they cool but before serving. If you're planning to serve the cakes without frosting or decorating them, you could serve them warm.

steps.headline: Frost the cakes if you want to make a chocolate layer cake.
steps.description: Set 1 cooled cake on a cake stand or plate and use an offset spatula to spread frosting over the top of the cake. Stack the other cooled cake on it and spread more frosting across the surface of the cake. Then, spread frosting around the sides of the layer cake. You could use any flavor of buttercream, chocolate ganache, or chocolate frosting, for instance. You'll need about 2 1/2 cups (0.5 kg) of your favorite frosting to cover the layer cake.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C) and spray a sheet pan with nonstick spray.
steps.description: Spray the bottom and sides of a 9 in × 13 in (23 cm × 33 cm) pan. If you don't have nonstick baking spray, coat the pan with softened butter and sprinkle flour into it. Turn the pan while you tap it to distribute the flour. Then, dump out the excess flour. Set the pan aside while you make the chocolate cake batter.

steps.headline: Whisk the flour, sugar, cocoa, baking soda, baking powder, and salt in a bowl.
steps.description: Put 2 cups (240 g) of all-purpose flour into a large mixing bowl along with 2 cups (400 g) of granulated sugar and 3/4 cup (88 g) of unsweetened cocoa powder. Add 2 teaspoons (8 g) of baking soda, 1 teaspoon (5 g) of baking powder, and 1 teaspoon (5 g) of salt. Then, whisk for about 30 seconds so the dry ingredients combine. Use a metal or glass mixing bowl instead of plastic since you'll be pouring boiling water into it. It's important to use unsweetened cocoa powder instead of a sweetened chocolate powder or drink mix. Sweetened mixes usually contain more sugar than cocoa powder, so your cake wouldn't have a rich chocolate flavor.

steps.headline: Add the buttermilk, oil, eggs, and vanilla to the bowl.
steps.description: Pour 1 cup (240 ml) of buttermilk into the bowl with the dry ingredients along with ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of vegetable oil. Add 2 large eggs and 2 teaspoons (9.9 ml) of vanilla extract.Tip: If you don't have buttermilk, stir 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of lemon juice or vinegar into 1 cup (240 ml) of milk. Leave it for 5 minutes at room temperature before adding it to the mixing bowl. The buttermilk contains lactic acid, which makes your chocolate cake light and moist.

steps.headline: Beat the mixture for 30 seconds to create a smooth batter.
steps.description: Turn a hand or stand mixer to medium speed and beat all of the ingredients so the wet ingredients are incorporated. You may want to stop and scrape down the sides of the bowl occasionally so the batter mixes evenly. If you don't have a hand or stand mixer, use a sturdy spatula to beat the batter by hand.

steps.headline: Stir in the boiling water on low speed.
steps.description: Turn the mixer down to low and slowly pour in 1 cup (240 ml) of boiling water while the mixer's going. Use caution when handling the boiling water. The boiling water loosens the batter and makes the cocoa flavor more intense. Turn off the mixer once you've beaten in all the water. Stop the mixer again and scrape down the sides of the bowl once you've mixed in the water.

steps.headline: Pour the batter into the pan and bake the cake for 32 to 37 minutes.
steps.description: Spoon the chocolate cake batter into the greased pan. Since the batter is so thin, you won't be able to spread it evenly. Then, bake the cake until it's done in the center. To test if the cake is done, wear oven mitts and insert a skewer or cake tester into the middle. The skewer should come out clean if the cake is finished. If it's still wet, bake the cake for a few minutes before checking again.

steps.headline: Cool the cake completely before covering it with your choice of frosting.
steps.description: Set the cake in the pan on a wire rack and leave it to cool completely. You can either leave it in the pan if you'd like to serve it from the pan or flip it onto the wire rack. Spread your choice of frosting over the top, leave it plain, dust it with powdered sugar, or serve it with a scoop of ice cream. Try coating the cake with buttercream, chocolate frosting, or ganache. Store the leftover cake in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 days.
